301-1 – Emotional and Physical Sexuality 1
Presented By: George J. Kappas, MA, LMFT, CCHt
Developed by HMI Founder Dr. John Kappas, PhD, LMFT, the model of Emotional and Physical Sexuality (E&P) is
without question, one of HMI’s most powerful tools for understanding and predicting the behavior of clients. In this
lesson, HMI Director and Marriage Family Therapist George Kappas will introduce you to the E&P model in a
presentation you are not likely to forget.
Completed: Thu, Sep 4, 2025 / Score: 100%
Workbook - Emotional and Physical Sexuality 1
Learning Objectives
Upon completion of this lesson, you will be able to:
Knowledge
Understand the significance of a Bi-Modal distribution.
Identify the Four Core Traits and why they are important.
Understand the E&P Priorities and how are they different from the Four Core Traits.
Be able to explain unique Kappas terminology.
Describe how Surface Traits are different and related to Core Traits.
Know how to seek and discover a client’s E&P personality.
Understand how we should be using the E&P online test with clients.
Comprehension
Understand the E&P model, its purpose, and its role in your hypnotherapy practice.
Application
Prepare to apply this model with clients in private practice.
Feel confident explaining and sharing this model with your clients.
Be competent to do the E&P homework with clients and help them interpret the results.
Learning Approach
Use this workbook as a guide for studying the video lecture and answering the questions outlined below. Be
prepared to answer the workbook questions in your Q&A with Instructor.
Work diligently on the E&P homework between classes 1 and 2, bring homework to the next class, and be
prepared to discuss.
Read the suggested text: Relationship Strategies, by Dr. John Kappas
Complete the open-book quiz.
Resources

Supplemental Videos

Emotional and Physical Sexuality
The Emotional and Physical Sexuality model was authored by Dr. John Kappas in the early 1970s and was a unique
and revolutionary model in that it completely dismissed gender as a basis for understanding and predicting behavior
in relationships. Many, if not most, relationship models then and today rely on gender as the main understanding of
behavior in relationships. Dr. Kappas relied on years of work with clients, as well as discussion, debate, and
comparisons with his colleagues at HMI, to further develop and refine the model.
The name “Emotional and Physical” can confuse the newly initiated if they take them literally. The “Emotional” does
not experience more “emotions” as the name might imply. Other suggested names for the Emotional, like the
“Intellectual,” were rejected because it implies that Emotionals are inherently smarter or have greater intellect, which
is not true and not suggested in Dr. Kappas’ model. Due to the long history of the terms at HMI, the Emotional and
Physical terms have been maintained. Any confusion is generally easily overcome by both students and clients alike.
The alternative terms “Emo” and “Phys” and just “E&P” are also used synonymously in the model and help
newcomers to the model to get past the literal meanings of Emotional and Physical.
During this lecture, it will appear as if we are talking about two completely separate categories of behavior; however,
it is best to view E&P as opposite sides of a spectrum. Each individual will favor one side of the spectrum over the
other; rarely is a person 100% of either category but rather a percentage of one over the other.
Emotional Sexuality – X – Physical Sexuality
100% - - - - - - - - - - - X - - - - - - - - - - - 100%
For simplicity, in this lesson, we will describe the Emotional and Physical Sexual as if each were 100% on
their side of the spectrum.
Generalizations in models are essential, despite the presence of exceptions. Focusing too much on exceptions can
hinder our understanding of the model.
When it comes to relationship behavior, there is no right or wrong – only differences. What makes this model unique
is its focus on two distinct personality types that operate below the level of awareness. These are referred to as
subconscious behaviors or subconscious personalities.
During the development of this model, a common pattern emerged: individuals are subconsciously drawn to others
who are their opposites at a subconscious level. This is not immediately apparent because, on a conscious level,
these individuals may appear very similar. They might share the same race, religion, political affiliation,
socioeconomic status, hobbies, and other visible traits. They could seem like clones on the surface, yet on a
subconscious level, they are complete opposites. These differences often become evident as the relationship
progresses, leading to potential conflict.
To further explore these dynamics, researchers developed a set of questionnaires to measure relationships. They
classified behaviors into two extremes to create a test. Individuals could score anywhere from 0% to 100% on either
the Emotional or Physical spectrum. When the results were plotted on a graph, they revealed a bimodal distribution –
two overlapping bell curves with two distinct peaks. On average, most people scored around 65% on the Physical
side and 65% on the Emotional side. These individuals were more likely to attract each other. Interestingly, the more
extreme an individual's score, the more extreme their partner's score tended to be on the opposite side. For example,
someone scoring 80% Physical would likely attract someone scoring 80% Emotional, and so forth.
This bimodal distribution explains the origins of conflict. When entering a new relationship, people often assume that
their partner thinks like they do, shares the same values, and prioritizes similar things. However, the subconscious
differences can lead to misunderstandings and tension over time.

The initial version of the Emotional and Physical (E&P) model was nicknamed the "silent conspiracy." This was based
on the observation that most therapists tended to score higher on the Physical personality scale. As a result, they
often viewed their own perspectives and approaches to relationships as the norm. If a client's perspective differed,
therapists might unknowingly attempt to "correct" them, failing to recognize that there are two equally valid sets of
norms. The authors of the model argued that this bias inadvertently marginalized the other 50% of the population –
those with Emotional personalities. This bias was not limited to therapists but was also reflected in societal norms,
further reinforcing the silent conspiracy against Emotional personalities.
Dr. Kappas coined the term “Buy the Symptoms” to describe an essential concept to improve relationships. It means
that when you're in a relationship with your partner, you must accept and embrace the very traits or behaviors that
might bother you – the differences you judge or struggle with. These "symptoms" are often the precise reasons you
were attracted to them in the first place.
Many people believe they want to be with someone just like them, thinking it would make life easier. However,
chances are, you've tried that before, and it didn’t work. Such relationships often become either too platonic or
riddled with conflict, as both partners compete for the same space. In reality, complementarity – being with someone
who balances you out – creates a stronger attraction, a more solid union, and a more functional relationship than
being with someone exactly like you on this scale.
“Buying the symptoms” means acknowledging that you are naturally drawn to individuals who are your opposites on
a subconscious level. It’s about understanding what those differences mean, how they manifest in your relationship,
and how to make them work in your favor.
How Sexuality is Developed
The three (3) primary goals of the model are, in order:
1. Understanding: To understand the behavior of oneself and partner in relationships so that it makes sense why
each partner behaves the way they do. This understanding reduces stress and increases tolerance and
acceptance of the differences between the two partners.
2. Predicting: The understanding of E&P behavior leads to the ability to predict E&P behavior. If one can predict
themselves or their partner’s response or behavior, it again provides greater tolerance, acceptance, and
compassion for themselves or their partner.
3. Shaping: If one can predict the response of themselves or their partner to a communication or response to a
situation and stimulus in the relationship, it gives them the option to reconsider that stimulus or re-word their
communication to receive the desired response. This option to choose allows the shaping of behavior for
themselves or their partners.
The Sexuality Test should be viewed as an introduction to the model, as self-administered tests come with an
inherent limitation: they are not entirely objective. When judging your own behavior, social desirability factors often
influence your responses. You tend to see yourself as you want to be seen, rather than as you are perceived by
others objectively.

Rules for this Lecture
To learn the basics of the E&P Sexuality model, please refrain from using any of these words and be careful not to
confuse the Sexuality model with any of this model.
Do not confuse the concept of E&P “Suggestibility” with “E&P Sexuality.” To avoid this confusion, we ban the
word “Suggestibility completely from this lesson.
Do not bring up the concepts or use the words “Defense Mechanism,” “Incongruency,” or “Ethnic Sexuality” in
this lesson. We will defer those concepts to E&P Part 2 to avoid confusion early on.
Goals for this Lecture
Watch the lecture carefully to gain a solid grasp on how we determine one’s E&P Score.
Learn the difference between using the E&P questionnaire vs. the more detailed approach of discovering the Four
Core Traits.
How are the Core Traits different from Surface Traits?
Be prepared to discuss these Four Core Traits in detail:
1. Family of Origin
2. Response to Rejection
3. Relationship to Physical Body
4. Patterns in Romantic Relationships
Understand why the Priorities of the E and the P differ, how it affects their relationship and how it is different from the
Four Core Traits.
Surface traits stem from and relate back to core traits, but not all traits are created equal. Surface traits are
associated with being either Emotional (E) or Physical (P), but they do not define what makes someone an E or P.
They are not the traits by which we should judge or categorize individuals.
pages.section_title: confuse the Sexuality model with any of this model.

pages.raw_text:
Dispelling Myths
Extroverts vs Introverts
“Physicals are extroverts, Emotionals are introverts.”
This is the most common misconception about the model. While we generally expect Physicals to be more
extroverted, a shy Physical or an Emotional who is extroverted due to their job, career, or specific training can
exist. This is merely a surface trait.
Emotional vs Logical
While Physicals are often more heart-driven and Emotionals more head-driven, this distinction is not a core trait.
Clothing Style or Appearance
Characteristics like long painted fingernails, the type of car one drives, flashy or conservative dress styles, or
wearing glasses are all surface traits and do not define one’s core personality.
Drawing Attention to Oneself
This is also a surface trait, not a defining feature of either type.
Life Priorities or Career Choices
These are surface traits and not directly indicative of one’s core personality.

The Four Core Traits
1. Relationship to the Physical Body
Physicals: Physicals have a strong connection with their physical body and process emotions through their
bodies and minds.
They experience emotions immediately and physically.
They don’t need to think about how they feel; it’s instinctive.
They interact with the world through their physical body, often expressing themselves through touch
and closeness.
Emotionals: Emotionals have a more disconnected relationship with their physical body and primarily
process emotions in their mind.
They may feel emotions without a physical response.
Their emotional reactions tend to be delayed and rationalized.
They interact with the world less through their body and are less certain about their feelings.
2. Response to Rejection
Physicals: Physicals tend to come forward and address feelings of rejection directly.
They are more likely to reach out, talk about the issue, and seek to repair the relationship.
Emotionals: Emotionals often withdraw or shut down when they feel rejected.
They wall off their emotions and detach themselves.
Example: If threatened with being fired at work, they might unconsciously quit first to avoid rejection.
3. Patterns in Romantic Relationships
Observing a person’s usual attractions and behavior in relationships can provide insights.
Emotionals are often attracted to Physicals, and Physicals are often attracted to Emotionals.
Past behavior is one of the best predictors of future behavior.
4. Family of Origin
A person’s behavior often reflects the dominant Secondary Caretaker observed during childhood, typically
the father in traditional family structures.
Understanding why the priorities of Emotionals and Physicals differ is key to understanding how these
differences influence relationships and the Four Core Traits.
Important Note: Each of the core traits alone is only 25% accurate in determining someone’s sexuality type.
Identifying two of the core traits increases the likelihood to 50%. To accurately determine someone’s sexuality type,
at least three out of the four core traits are required.

Surface Traits

Thinks before reacting

Wants alone time
Dresses for comfort
Decides after thinking about it
Speaks literally to the point
Infers from what others say
Feels emotional pain in the mind
Fears loss of security
Physical Tendencies

Enjoys socializing in groups

Comfortable with affection anytime

Enjoys team activities

Feels emotional pain in body and mind

Differences Between the E&P Model and Traditional Marriage or Relationship
Models
Non-Gender-Based Model
This model rejects gender stereotypes and abandons the notion that men and women behave in fixed,
specific ways. It does not require knowledge of gender to predict behavior.
Rejects Sexual Orientation
The model applies to individuals regardless of their sexual orientation. It works equally well for
heterosexual, homosexual, or other types of couples.
Challenges Parental-Based Marriage Myths
Rejects the idea that girls marry someone like their fathers and boys marry someone like their mothers.
Instead, this model suggests that everyone grows up to marry someone who mirrors their mother’s
behavior. Through observation, people tend to model the behavior of their secondary caretaker, often
resulting in marrying someone with opposite behaviors.
Can Sexuality Change from Emo to Phys or Vice Versa?
While Sexuality cannot be changed, it is flexible. It is triggered in different ways at different times. Our behavior can
ebb and flow with different relationships. This means there is a critical stage during childhood where this personality
type solidifies (from 9-15). By around the age of 12 or 13, neuroplasticity in this area closes, and your sexuality type
becomes cemented for life. It is a lifelong personality that does not change.
Understanding Rejection in Relationships
Rejection plays a significant role in the dynamics between Emotionals and Physicals, but it often manifests differently
for each type.
Physicals: Physicals may claim they rejected their partner, but upon closer examination, they are often
responding to subtle, prolonged rejection from the Emotional. They eventually reach a breaking point, feeling
they can’t take it anymore, and end the relationship. However, this act of "ending" is frequently a reaction to the
rejection they’ve experienced over time.
Emotionals: Emotionals tend to avoid confrontation, especially with Physicals. They are not naturally good
confronters and often engage in subtle, passive-aggressive forms of rejection. Over time, this subtle rejection
builds up until it becomes overwhelming for the Physical, leading to an eventual breakup.
Emotionals often want the Physical to end the relationship so they can exit without feeling guilt. Since
Emotionals intellectualize their emotions, avoiding guilt becomes a significant motivation. By rationalizing
the situation and denying their role in the rejection, they can distance themselves from responsibility.
This pattern highlights a common negative trait of Emotionals: the tendency to subtly reject their partner and avoid
accountability for the relationship's decline.
pages.section_title: Differences Between the E&P Model and Traditional Marriage or Relationship

pages.raw_text:
Common Patterns
Rebound Relationships in the E&P Model
When a Physical is subtly rejected in a relationship by an Emotional, leading to a breakup, there is often a tendency
for the rebound relationship to involve another Physical – usually someone higher on the Physical scale. However,
when two dominant individuals come together, the dynamic can shift, often resulting in platonic friendships or
conflicts due to competing dominance.
The Rebound Cycle
Emotional Fallout: Following the breakup, the Physical experiences emotional pain and feelings of rejection.
Over time, loneliness and a desire for recovery lead them to seek a new partner.
In their previous relationship, the Emotional partner likely stopped complimenting them and providing
emotional support, leaving the Physical feeling unattractive and undesired.
In the rebound relationship, the new Physical partner often fulfills these unmet needs, offering compliments,
physical attraction, and validation.
Initial Fulfillment:
In these rebound relationships, the new partner makes the Physical feel beautiful, desired, and valued –
everything they were missing before.
For a time, this feels like exactly what the Physical needed to heal their self-esteem.
Emerging Conflicts:
Over time, the Physical begins to miss key aspects of their identity in the relationship, such as being the
dominant and spontaneous leader.
In this new relationship, they often play the role of the Emotional partner, which feels safer but not entirely
authentic to their nature.
Dominance Clashes:
Physicals tend to dominate in relationships, and when two Physicals come together, they may clash for
dominance.
These relationships often end in one of two ways: the partnership becomes platonic or combative
Recovery and Return to Emotional Partners
Sometimes, a Physical may go through one or two rebound relationships with other Physicals before fully recovering.
Once they rebuild their self-esteem and confidence, they may feel ready to be vulnerable again. This often leads
them back to an Emotional partner, seeking a longer-term, more meaningful connection.
Rebound relationships with other Physicals tend to be shorter in duration, serving as a transitional phase. A longer
relationship with an Emotional partner afterward typically signifies the Physical’s readiness to engage in deeper
emotional vulnerability again. These patterns highlight not only a high-Physical personality but also the cyclical nature
of healing and connection in relationships.
pages.section_title: Rebound Relationships in the E&P Model

pages.raw_text:
Reasons for Infidelity
Physicals: Cheat to relieve the pain of rejection and seek acceptance.
For Physicals, infidelity is often a response to the deep emotional and physical pain caused by rejection
from their partner. They feel deprived of emotional connection, physical touch, and intimacy, which they
experience as a tangible pain. Cheating offers temporary relief from this pain and provides a sense of
acceptance and validation.
Physicals typically cheat with other rejected Physicals who are experiencing similar pain and needs.
Initially, this dynamic feels good as they fulfill each other’s immediate emotional voids, but deeper issues
often arise once these immediate needs are met.
Subconsciously, they want to be caught by their partner. Their reasoning is twofold:
They hope their partner will experience the pain they felt from rejection
They believe that if their partner understands the hurt, they will change their behavior and reengage in
the relationship.
However, this rarely has the desired effect. In most cases, being caught relieves the Emotional of guilt,
enabling them to walk away from the relationship without regret. Often, guilt was the main factor keeping
the Emotional in the relationship in the first place.
Emotionals: Cheat due to emotional shutdown or a lack of attraction.
Emotionals cheat for entirely different reasons. Their infidelity stems from gradually shutting down
emotionally, losing attraction to their partner, and feeling that something is missing in the relationship. They
seek to replace what they perceive as lacking.
When Emotionals cheat, it is not necessarily due to unhappiness with their family or partnership. For them,
it’s often purely a sexual matter, with a clear separation between their emotions and physical actions.
Emotionals are more likely to have ongoing affairs that remain undiscovered.
They avoid confronting the Physical because they find Physicals difficult to address.
Financial security concerns may also prevent them from jeopardizing the relationship.
Power Dynamics in Relationships
Everyone seeks a sense of power in a relationship, but Physicals and Emotionals approach it differently:
Physicals often dominate the relationship by:
Guiding decisions and determining daily activities.
Occupying space and taking control of interactions.
Making many small decisions that add up to an overarching dominance. Over time, this dominance can
lead to resentment from the Emotional partner.
Since Emotionals cannot out-dominate a dominant partner, they balance the power dynamic through subtle acts
of rejection. This rejection allows them to reclaim some control in the relationship, albeit in an indirect way.

Counseling for Less Conflict
Understanding Behavioral Dominance: If someone is 65% Physical, they are dominant on the Physical side,
with 35% Emotional traits. People are rarely black-and-white in their behaviors.
Individuals closer to the center of the scale (e.g., 55% Physical and 45% Emotional) are more likely to
experience less conflict in relationships. They have overlapping behaviors that make compatibility easier.
Highly dominant individuals on either side of the scale (e.g., 70% and above) are more prone to conflicts,
as their behaviors are more extreme and contrasting.
De-Exaggerating Behaviors:
A strategy to reduce conflict involves “de-exaggerating” behavior by encouraging individuals to dial back
their dominant traits slightly (e.g., reducing by 10%). This minor adjustment can create a 20% swing in the
dynamics, fostering better compatibility and comfort in the relationship.
By understanding and accepting the opposite behaviors of their partner, individuals can relieve much of the
stress caused by misunderstandings.
If an Emotional wants to reduce their Physical partner’s neediness or jealousy, they can make their partner
feel more secure by showing their partner they are desired, making them feel wanted. Providing these
reassurances fulfills the Physical’s needs (or “Twinkies”) and helps lower their dominant Physical traits. As
these needs are met, their intensity naturally decreases over time.
Physicals should allow the Emotional space and wait for them to come forward. Giving Emotionals this
space respects their needs and enables the relationship to balance naturally.
Systemic Change:
Understanding that partners are opposites allows for a greater sense of acceptance and reduces
frustration. When individuals recognize that their partner’s behavior stems from their personality type, it
lowers stress and minimizes perceived issues.
Changing one partner’s behavior naturally impacts the other. In systemic relationships, lowering one
person’s exaggerated behaviors tends to reduce the other’s as well, creating balance and harmony.
Accommodating Differences:
Recognizing and accommodating the differences between Physicals and Emotionals leads to more
functional relationships. Acceptance of these behavioral contrasts is key to building mutual understanding
and reducing conflict.

Emotional Priorities
Career/Financial Security
Hobbies/Friends
Relationship/Family
Sex
Physical Priorities
Relationship/Sex
Family
Hobbies/Friends
Career/Financial Security
Notes: Priorities are surface traits and not definitive in judging sexuality. For Emotionals, financial security can be a
priority, even if they are not the primary breadwinner. For example, the Physical may earn the money, while the
Emotional manages or organizes it, reflecting their concern for security.
Friendship Patterns
Physical Males: Physical males tend to have other physical males as friends. They bond through shared
physical activities, such as group sports, and express connection through physical gestures.
Emotional Females: Emotional females typically bond with other emotional females. A common theme among
these groups is the presence of a physical male partner at home, whom they may avoid through these
gatherings. This dynamic often creates a sense of safety and camaraderie within the group.
Physical Females: Physical females are more likely to have male friends, often enjoying being the only female
in a group of males. They may have had past sexual relationships with some members of the group but now
maintain platonic connections. This dynamic allows them to enjoy attention without competition.
Emotional Males: Emotional males often struggle to form friendships. If they do, they are most likely to have a
physical male friend or past relationships with physical females. Emotional males typically connect better one-
on-one with a physical male than in a group setting. Relationships between two emotional males are rare and
often challenging to sustain without the balance provided by a physical counterpart.

Celebrity E&P Game (Guessing their Sexuality)
Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie: Physical and Emotional
Madonna and Sean Penn: Emotional and Physical
George W. Bush and Barbara Bush: Physical and Emotional
Barack and Michelle Obama: Emotional and Physical
Bill Clinton and Hillary Clinton: Physical and Emotional
Arnold Schwarzenegger and Maria Shriver: Physical and Emotional
Donald Trump and Melania Trump: Physical and Emotional
Sexual Priorities for Emotionals vs Physicals
Emotionals: For Emotionals, sex serves as a way to temporarily connect with their physical body, which they
often feel disconnected from. During sex, they experience a flood of physical sensations and emotions, making
them momentarily more attuned to their bodies. However, after the act, they may experience a dip or letdown, as
sex does not inherently signify love, safety, or security for them.
Physicals: For Physicals, sex is deeply tied to love, acceptance, intimacy, and security. It is a primary way they
express and receive affection, needing the physical connection to feel safe and loved. For them, sex is not just
about the act itself – it communicates closeness, attraction, and emotional connection.
Key Differences in Meaning
For Emotionals:
Sex is about temporarily bridging the gap between their emotions and their physical body.
It is not about expressing love but about experiencing physical sensations and connecting to their body.
For Physicals:
Sex is a form of emotional communication.
It provides safety, security, and love, serving as a vital way to express affection and bond.
Understanding these differences helps both partners better accommodate each other's needs, fostering deeper
connections and reducing misunderstandings in their relationship.

What did Dr. Kappas mean by these unique E&P terms?
Buy the Symptoms
Accepting your partner’s traits (“symptoms”), even those that might bother you, and acknowledging that this
oppositeness makes the relationship dynamic and creates the attraction on a subconscious level.
“As you recognize that the differences in your behaviors are not personal attacks and learn not to
take them personally, you will be able to open the door to learning how to sustain the benefits that
your differences afford each of you. Then you will be able to apply proven concepts to maintain the
balance necessary to fulfill the needs of two differing styles of personality.”
Give them a Twinkie
Provide your partner with something from their priority list rather than your own. For example, if the Emotional partner
prioritizes career success, the Physical can offer time and space to focus on their work or hobbies. Conversely, a
Physical may need physical affection and validation, which the Emotional can express through small gestures like a
note or a compliment, making them feel desired.
Cycle Days
Emotionals experience heightened sexual desire approximately every third day. The concept of cycle days is most
applicable during the plateau stages of relationships when everything is “normal” (after the Honeymoon Stage).
1. Day 1: Disconnected from their physical body, prioritizing hobbies or career.
2. Day 2: Middle phase, neutral.
3. Day 3: Most connected to their physical body, making intimacy and sexual connection a priority.
Negative experiences of rejection in this dynamic can extend the cycle, potentially leading to longer gaps in intimacy.
Honeymoon Stage
Every relationship begins with a honeymoon stage, marked by fascination and heightened sexual chemistry. In this
Stage, Emotionals behave more like Physicals, pursuing their partner more, drawn to the connection and novelty
their partner provides. Physicals behave less dominantly as the Emotional’s pursuit balances their usual need to
come forward. They feel comfortable and confident when they feel wanted and pursued by their Emo partner.

Cycle Days and the Honeymoon Stage
What are “Cycle Days”? How do they relate to the Honeymoon Stage?
During the honeymoon stage, the Emotional is more interested in frequent sexual intercourse. After the honeymoon
stage, that behavior comes back to “normal”, and their sexual desire peaks every third day.
In the Honeymoon Stage, the Emotional tends to behave more Physical. Why?
The Emotional partner, intrigued and mentally stimulated by his or her Physical lover, behaves in a manner which
appears more Physical than Emotional. The Emotional is suddenly interested in frequent intercourse and other
sexual activities. He or she is delighted to concentrate on pleasing the partner, because of the novelty of watching
the responses of a new and different individual, possessed by that fascinating “otherness.”
In the Honeymoon Stage, the Physical tends to behave less Physical. Why?
During the honeymoon stage, the Emotional behaves more like a Physical, pursuing their Physical partner more,
which means the Physical won’t need to come forward as much. The Emo behavior will naturally lessen the Physical
dominance of the Physical partner.
Other Important Questions and Concepts to Grasp
Why is the Emotional attracted to the Physical and vice versa?
Opposites attract because complementary differences enhance the relationship. This dynamic creates balance,
allowing each partner to feel whole by compensating for their weaknesses with the other’s strengths.
Why isn’t it better for E’s to be with E’s and P’s to be with P’s?
Two Emotionals may feel emotionally distant, focusing on separate priorities without a strong bond. Two Physicals
will often clash due to their shared need for dominance, which can lead to frequent conflicts. “Too much similarity
causes us to drift away, uninterested, unchallenged.”
When and how is it appropriate to incorporate this concept into your hypnotherapy
practice?
E&P theory is most useful when a client aims to improve their relationship with a partner, re-trigger the honeymoon
stage, or attract a compatible partner. It’s not necessary to ask about sexuality type in the first session – it depends
on the client’s presenting issues.
Define and discuss Dominance vs Sub-Dominance.
Dominance: Refers to the partner’s primary behavioral traits (e.g., 60% Physical).
Sub-Dominance: Reflects the secondary traits that appear less frequently (e.g., 40% Emotional).
For example, when someone is 60% Physical sexual, it means that roughly 60% of the time, they will act out the
characteristics of a Physical sexual; this is their dominant behavior. Approximately 40% of the time, though, they will
exhibit traits of the Emotional Sexual; this is their sub-dominant behavior.
Define and discuss Primary vs Secondary Caretaker.
Primary Caretaker: Often the mother or a mother figure.

Secondary Caretaker: Often the father or a substitute (e.g., an aunt, uncle, or teacher). Sexuality is influenced
by observing the Secondary Caretaker between ages 9 and 15. If a substitute caretaker exists, sexuality
develops from comparing their traits to the primary caretaker.

Your E&P Homework Assignments
Your E&P homework assignments are a key ingredient for discovering the E&P personality of yourself and your
clients. The more effort, time, and consideration you put into these exercises, the more you will understand your
behavior and the E&P model in general. Please bring your work with you to E&P Part 2 and be prepared to discuss.
Your E&P Family Tree
Follow the model used in the lecture. You can omit family members that you have little or no knowledge of.
Your Romantic Relationship Inventory
Make a list of all your “significant” romantic relationships from approximately the age of 20 to the present. List
them in order. Under no circumstances should you share this with your current partner.
Important Note: This assignment may have the potential to bring up painful feelings and experiences from the past.
Please use your best judgment whether this assignment is right for you. It is recommended, not required.
List and Discuss the Following for Each Relationship
Duration: How many months or years did the relationship last?
Who pursued who in the beginning?
How would you rate the “intensity” of the relationship emotionally/sexually?
How vulnerable to rejection did you feel during this relationship?
How did you respond to rejection vs. how did they respond to rejection during the relationship?
Who withdrew affection/love first?
Whom would you say was the E, and who was the P in this relationship?

Continuing Education Opportunities

by John G. Kappas, Ph.D.

It seems that some screenwriters have a keen sense of the E&P dynamic. We would love to hear which movie
you think illustrates E&P best. Here is the trailer for George’s favorite and most comprehensive E&P movie of all
time.
